spanish.tip_en: In Spanish, 'ma√±ana' can mean both 'tomorrow' AND 'morning'. Context helps: 'ma√±ana por la ma√±ana' = tomorrow morning.

spanish.description_en: Describe your family members and talk about relationships.
spanish.tip_en: 'Mi familia es muy importante para m√≠' (My family is very important to me). Use 'tengo' (I have) to talk about family: 'Tengo un hermano' (I have a brother).

spanish.description_en: Learn body parts and describe health issues in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: To say something hurts: 'Me duele + body part' ‚Üí 'Me duele la cabeza' (My head hurts). For plural: 'Me duelen los pies' (My feet hurt).

spanish.description_en: Order food and navigate a Spanish menu with confidence.
spanish.tip_en: In Spanish restaurants: lunch (la comida) is the main meal at 2-3pm! 'Quisiera...' (I would like...) is polite. Ask for 'la cuenta' (the bill) when done.

spanish.description_en: Navigate Spanish cities, buy tickets, and ask for directions.
spanish.tip_en: Ask directions: '¬øC√≥mo llego a...?' (How do I get to...?). Directions: recto/todo recto (straight), a la derecha (right), a la izquierda (left), gira (turn).

spanish.description_en: Master the most important Spanish verbs for daily conversation.
spanish.tip_en: SER vs ESTAR is the hardest concept for Spanish learners! SER = permanent identity (Soy m√©dico). ESTAR = temporary state (Estoy cansado). Practice both every day!

spanish.description_en: Describe people, places, and things using Spanish adjectives.
spanish.tip_en: Adjectives agree with nouns: grande (big) stays grande for all, but bonito (m) ‚Üí bonita (f). Most -o adjectives become -a for feminine.

spanish.description_en: Master the two Spanish verbs meaning 'to be' ‚Äî the most important distinction in Spanish!

grammar.intro_en: Spanish has TWO verbs meaning 'to be': SER (permanent/inherent) and ESTAR (temporary/changeable). This has NO equivalent in Bengali ‚Äî it's a uniquely Spanish challenge!

spanish.description_en: Conjugate -ar, -er, -ir verbs in the Spanish present tense.

grammar.intro_en: Spanish verbs end in -ar, -er, or -ir. Each type has its own set of endings in the present tense. The good news: -er and -ir are almost the same!

sections.note_en: Remove -ar and add: -o, -as, -a, -amos, -√°is, -an. Other -ar verbs: comer‚Üíno! trabajar (work), estudiar (study), escuchar (listen), caminar (walk).
Remove -er and add: -o, -es, -e, -emos, -√©is, -en. Other -er verbs: beber (drink), leer (read), vender (sell), correr (run).

spanish.description_en: Talk about completed past actions using the Pret√©rito Indefinido.

grammar.intro_en: The Pret√©rito Indefinido is used for completed actions in the past with a specific time. 'Ayer com√≠ arroz' (Yesterday I ate rice). It's like the simple past in English.

sections.note_en: Note: 'nosotros hablamos' is the SAME for present and past! Context tells you which one.
The accent marks are CRUCIAL: habl√≥ (he spoke) vs habl√≥ (it doesn't mean anything without context). Accents differentiate past from present: habl√≥ ‚â† hablo.

spanish.description_en: Talk about future plans using IR A + infinitive and the simple future.

grammar.intro_en: Just like French, Spanish has two ways to express the future: (1) IR A + infinitive (going to...) for near future plans, and (2) Futuro Simple (will...) for predictions and promises.

sections.note_en: This is the most common future in everyday spoken Spanish. 'Voy a estudiar esta tarde' (I'm going to study this afternoon).
All -ar, -er, -ir verbs use the same endings: -√©, -√°s, -√°, -emos, -√©is, -√°n. Add to the FULL infinitive (not just the stem)!

spanish.description_en: Master practical phrases for real-life situations in Spain.
spanish.tip_en: Practice tip: Write 3 sentences about your day using these phrases every evening. After one month, you'll be amazed at your progress!

spanish.description_en: Essential vocabulary for doctors, pharmacies, symptoms, and healthcare in Spain.
spanish.tip_en: In Spain, say 'Me duele la cabeza' (My head hurts). Spain has excellent free healthcare ‚Äî go to the 'centro de salud' (health centre) for non-emergencies.

spanish.description_en: Furniture, rooms, household items and daily home life vocabulary in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: In Spain, 'el piso' means apartment (flat), not floor! 'Alquilar un piso' = to rent an apartment. Very useful vocabulary for your PhD life in Spain!

spanish.description_en: Talking about sports, hobbies, and leisure activities in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: Football is a religion in Spain! 'jugar al f√∫tbol' (to play football), 'el partido' (the match), 'el equipo' (the team). Knowing this vocabulary helps you bond with Spanish people!

spanish.tip_en: Spanish weather: '¬øQu√© tiempo hace?' (What's the weather like?). 'Hace calor' (it's hot) ‚Äî very relevant in Spain! 'Hace fr√≠o' (it's cold), 'Llueve' (it rains).

spanish.description_en: Professional vocabulary ‚Äî jobs, workplace, meetings, studies and academic life in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: 'Soy investigador/a' (I am a researcher). In Spanish universities: 'el doctorado' = PhD, 'el laboratorio' = lab, 'la tesis' = thesis ‚Äî your daily words!

spanish.description_en: Shopping vocabulary ‚Äî clothes, sizes, prices and fashion expressions in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: Asking the price: '¬øCu√°nto cuesta?' or '¬øCu√°nto vale?' Spain has great markets ‚Äî 'el mercadillo' (flea market) and 'las rebajas' (sales in January & July)!

spanish.description_en: Describing people, professions, community services and social interactions in Spanish.
spanish.tip_en: Spanish social life: 'dar un abrazo' (giving a hug) and 'dos besos' (two cheek kisses) are common greetings. 'la comunidad de vecinos' = residents' community in apartments.

spanish.description_en: Advanced food vocabulary ‚Äî ingredients, Spanish cuisine, tapas culture and restaurant language.
spanish.tip_en: 'Las tapas' (small snacks with drinks) are a Spanish tradition. 'ir de tapas' = going out for tapas. 'La cuenta, por favor' = the bill, please ‚Äî very important!

spanish.tip_en: Spain's AVE (Alta Velocidad Espa√±ola) high-speed trains are excellent! Buy tickets on Renfe.com. 'El AVE a Madrid' connects major cities. 'El metro' is the best way around cities.

spanish.tip_en: Nationalities agree with gender: espa√±ol ‚Üí espa√±ola. Most end in -o/-a. 'Soy banglades√≠' ‚Äî same form for M/F! Never capitalise: 'soy espa√±ol', not 'Espa√±ol'.

spanish.tip_en: Use 'suelo + infinitive' for habits: 'Suelo levantarme a las 7' (I usually get up at 7). Reflexive verbs need pronouns: me levanto, te duchas, se levanta.

spanish.tip_en: For activities: 'Hago yoga / Hago senderismo / Hago snowboard.' For sports with ball: 'Juego al f√∫tbol / al ajedrez.' For instruments: 'Toco la guitarra.'

grammar.intro_en: Spanish past narration often mixes two tenses: imperfecto for background, habits and descriptions, and pret√©rito indefinido for completed actions that move the story forward.
